under this section shall bear interest at the rate of 18% per annum from the due date of the return until the first day of the month following the month in which the tax is paid or deposited with the clerk an extension of time within which to file a return shall not operate to extend the due date of the return for purposes of interest computation 12 delinquent returns  late filing fee and negligence penalty am #1110 a there shall be a late fee of $10 imposed for not filing a return by the due date b there shall be a negligence penalty imposed equal to 5% of the tax due for each month or part of a month the return is filed after the due date the maximum negligence penalty for late filing is 25% of the tax due 13 security deposit am #0104 in order to protect the revenue of the city the city clerk may require any person liable for the tax imposed by this section to place with himher before or after a permit is issued such security not in an excess of an amount equal to the maximum possible revenue to be derived from said property per quarter of operation to be determined by the city clerk if any taxpayer fails or refuses to place such security the city clerk may refuse or revoke such permit if any taxpayer is delinquent in payment of the taxes imposed by this section the city clerk may upon 10 days notice recover the taxes interest and penalties from the security placed with the city clerk by such taxpayer no interest shall be paid or allowed by the city to any person for the deposit of such security 14 records required every person liable for the tax imposed by this section shall keep or cause to be kept such records receipts invoices and other pertinent information essential to the proper recording and payment of said tax 15 confidentiality of returns am #0104 all tax returns schedules exhibits writings or audit reports relating to such returns on file with the city clerk are deemed to be confidential except the city clerk may divulge their contents to the following and no others a the person who filed the return b officers agents or employees of the federal internal revenue service or the state department of revenue c officers employees or agent of the city as may be deemed necessary to enforce collection 16 confidentiality of records no person having an administrative duty under this section shall make known in any manner the business affairs operations or information obtained by an investigation of records of any person on whom a tax is imposed by this section or the amount or source of income profits losses expenditures or any particular thereof set forth or disclosed in any return or to permit any return or copy thereof to be seen or examined by any person except as provided in sub 15 above or by order of a court 17 penalties a any person subject to the room tax who fails to comply with a request to inspect and audit the persons financial records shall be subject to a forfeiture of 5% of the tax imposed or determined under sub 10 above b any person subject to the room tax who fails to pay the tax imposed shall be subject to a forfeiture determined as follows 25% of the room tax due for the previous year or $5000 whichever is less c any person who is subject to the tax imposed who fails to obtain a permit as required in sub 4 above or who fails to file a return as provided in this section or who violates any other provision of this section shall be subject to a forfeiture not to exceed $200 each day or portion thereof that such violation continues is hereby deemed to constitute a separate offense d any person violating the confidentiality provisions of subs 15 and 16 may be required to forfeit not less than $100 nor more than $500 18 administrative cost  hotel and motel room tax fund hotel and motel room tax committee cr #689  am #1110 a the permit fees late filing fees and forfeitures together with 5% of the revenues collected from the room tax shall be directed by the city clerk to the citys general fund to cover administrative costs of this section b the balance of the revenues collected from the tax shall be directed by the clerk to be held in a separate hotelmotel tax fund all expenditures from the hotelmotel tax fund shall be under the jurisdiction of the finance committee c there shall be a room tax committee which shall consist of one city staff person one council member at large a minimum of 2 lodging representatives one waupaca area chamber of commerce representative and a minimum of 2 at large tourism related business representatives from within the city of waupaca the total members of the committee shall be at least 7 and no more than 9 the committee shall receive applications for funds and make recommendations to the finance committee and to council as to the distributions of money from the hotelmotel tax fund l9 hotelmotel tax distribution cr #0506 the revenue generated from the increase of the tax from 50% to 80% shall be distributed as follows a 70% of proceeds to the chamber of commerce to assist with funding a full time tourism director in the chamber  and b 30% of proceeds to the city general fund for the purposes of funding the city development director position 309  alternative claim procedure for refunds of tax payments in excess of tax bill amounts  cr #299 1 purpose and intent it is the declared intent of this section that tax payments made in excess of the tax bill amounts shall be refunded pursuant to the procedures established under this section within 15 business days of the payment further it is the declared intent that this policy shall be in full force and effect upon adoption by the council with the purpose of complying with 74032 wis stats 2 authority this section is adopted pursuant to the authority granted to a council under  wis stats to enact an alternative system for approving financial claims against the city other than claims under 89380 wis stats 3 required procedures of the city treasurer upon payment of excess amount over tax bill amount upon receipt of tax payments in excess of the tax bill the city treasurer shall deposit as soon as practicable all payments in the name of the city in public depositories designated by the council upon verification by the treasurer that the payment as deposited has cleared and not been returned as insufficient funds but not later than 10 days after depositing the treasurer shall notify the city clerk in writing of the name and mailing address of the taxpayer for whom a refund in excess of the tax bill amount is due the amount of the refund in excess of the tax bill the date payment was received and a statement that the payment as made has cleared and not been returned as insufficient funds 4 required procedures of city clerk upon notification from the city treasurer of excess payment of tax bill amount upon written notification from the city treasurer that a taxpayer has made a tax payment in excess of the tax bill amount the city clerk shall approve a claim as a proper charge against the city treasury and shall endorse hisher approval on the claim after having determined that the following conditions have been complied with a the funds are available to pay the claim assuming the tax payment has cleared and has not been returned as is evidenced by the treasurers notice b the council has authorized the refund of excess tax payment as established by the adoption of this section c the refund is due in the amount noticed by the treasurer as a tax payment in excess of the amount of the tax bill d the refund is a valid claim against the city being a payment in excess of the tax bill amount further the clerk shall prepare monthly and file with the council a list of claims paid under this procedure listing the amount of the claims the date paid the name of the taxpayerclaimant and that the payment was a payment of a refund for excess tax payment 5 issuance of disbursement from the city treasury upon approval of the claim or proper authorization by the city clerk under the procedures listed in sub 4 above a refund check payable to the taxpayerclaimant named in the claim or authorization and in the amount approved shall be written by the city treasurer countersigned as required by  wis stats by the clerk and the treasurer unless facsimile signatures approved by the council are used shall be issued not later than 15 business days from the date the tax payment was received by the treasurer as noticed by the treasurer in sub 3 above 6 mailing or delivery of refund check to taxpayerclaimant upon issuance of the proper countersigned refund check pursuant to the procedures in this section the refund check shall be delivered to the taxpayerclaimant or mailed to the last known mailing address of the taxpayerclaimant by the city treasurer 7 audit required  city clerks bond pursuant to 3 wis stats the council hereby is required to contract for an annual detailed audit of its financial transactions and accounts by a public accountant licensed under ch 442 wis stats and designated by the council the city clerk shall be covered by a fidelity bond of not less than $5000 310  public fire protection charges  cr #1800 1 applicability all real property including property exempted from taxation pursuant to 7011 wis stats is subject to the public fire protection charges real property includes not only the land itself but all the buildings and improvements thereon and all fixtures and rights and privileges appertaining thereto as set forth in 7003 wis stats 2 effective date the public fire protection pfp charge shall be effective with the december 2000 billing period collectible in january 2001 3 rate the public fire protection charge is computed by taking the total amount of the assessed value of all taxable property and the effective assessed value of all tax exempt property in the city and dividing this figure into the cost of fire protection effective assessed value means the value placed on the property by the city for purposes of the public fire protection charge and is the same value that would apply to the property if it were taxable and assessed under 7032 wis stats fire protection costs within the city water utility include hydrants hydrant maintenance and indirect costs associated with water capacity and production the resulting rate is expressed as a cost per thousand of value for purposes of implementation of this section the rate if 63 per thousand 4 determining value of tax exempt property the administrative staff is directed to develop a return form that will be sent to each owner of tax exempt real property in the city limits in order to determine property value the return shall be completed by the property owner and shall contain the fair market value of the property which shall be based on recent arms length sales of the property and recent arms length sales of reasonably comparable property and any other factors that according to professionally acceptable appraisal practices affect the value of the property for purposes of the public fire protection pfp charge tax exempt real property owners may also use the replacement value land and improvements placed on the property by the owner for property insurance purposes there shall be annexed to such return the declaration of such person or of the managing agent or officer of such firm or corporation that the statements therein are true the city reserves the right for verification purposes to require that each exempt real property owner provide a copy of the insurance certificate upon request the effective assessed value shall be determined by the city and may be based on the property owners return and also insurance valuations appraisals assessors office determinations and cost information if recent any person firm or corporation who fails neglects or refuses to make and file a return required by this section shall be denied any right to appeal or otherwise contest the value placed on the property by the city the return shall be completed and filed with the city clerks office within 30 days of receipt of the return form 5 billing the annual charge shall be divided and billed in 12 equal installments should the annual bill be below $25 the city reserves the right to charge single billing sent out by july 15 of each year 6 nonpayment of charge the pfp charge shall be billed with and be a part of the monthly utility bill utility service may be disconnected or refused for failure to pay a delinquent account in accordance with wis adm 37 delinquent accounts shall be collected in the manner provided by law including the public service commission rules and regulations 7 nonutility customers the public fire protection pfp charge shall be applied to all real properties within the city including nonimproved parcels vacant land nonimproved properties are not currently receiving utility services as a result the city utility billing staff shall add all vacant land to the utility billing listing and shall use the assessed value of the land in determining the annual pfp charge 8 residentialcommercial rentals the occupant of a rentedleased premises is typically the utility customer and therefore shall be responsible for paying the pfp charge to calculate the monthly pfp charge the city staff shall use the following guidelines to determine property value a residential rentals 1 master meters for residential rental buildings with a master meter the owner shall be billed and responsible for the entire pfp charge based on the assessed value of the buildings including land 2 individualseparate unit meters the renter or utility customer on the account is responsible for the pfp charge the city shall take the total value of the building including land and apportion the value equally across all rental units in the building b commercial rentals 1 master meters the owner of the building shall be billed and responsible for the entire pfp charge based on the value of the building including land 2 individual meters the city shall take the total assessed value of the building including land to determine a value per square foot included in the calculation are the common areas of the building ie entryways closets and other storage space and bathrooms the square foot value shall then be applied to the square footage of each business suite 9 jurisdiction the finance committee shall be the committee to oversee the implementation of the public fire protection pfp charge chapter 4  police department 401 police department 402 chief of police powers and duties 403 assistant chief duties 404 police powers 405 who may arrest 406 search and seizure 407 police to inspect taverns 408 fires and assemblages 409 residency requirements 410 badge to be displayed 411 arrests persons called to assist 412 interfering with or resisting police officer 413 police not to give bail 414 regulation of emergency alarm systems 420 penalty 401  police department  1 composition the police department shall consist of the chief of police the assistant chief and such number of subordinates as the mayor and the council shall from time to time deem necessary 2 appointment  terms the police and fire commission shall appoint the chief of police who shall hold office during good behavior subject to suspension or removal by the commission for cause the chief shall appoint subordinates subject to approval by the commission such appointments shall be made by promotion when this can be done with advantage  otherwise from an eligible list provided by examination and approval by the commission and kept on file with the city clerk 3 regulations members of the department shall be governed by the rules and regulations adopted by the police and fire commission resolutions and ordinances adopted by the council and the wisconsin statutes 4 disciplinary actions disciplinary actions regarding the chief and other members of the department shall be governed by 62135 wis stats 402  chief of police powers and duties  1 supervision the chief of police shall have command of the police force heshe shall see that all laws rules regulations ordinances resolutions and orders of every kind applicable within the city set forth by the wisconsin statutes the council and the police and fire commission are enforced 15 police department policies cr #788 the chief of police shall establish policies for the police department regarding the following a use of force b citizen complaint procedures in accordance with the provisions of  wis stats c all other policies as may be mandated from time to time by the statutes of the state of wisconsin cr #0404 2 arrest the chief shall cause to be arrested all persons who shall be found violating any ordinances or regulations of the city and all persons chargeable with offenses punishable by the laws of the state and shall bring such persons before the proper tribunal 3 police record the chief shall keep an accurate and complete record of all complaints arrests traffic violations convictions and the disposition of each case handled by the department the chief shall also keep a record of the accomplishments and performances of each police officer 4 annual report the chief shall following the end of each calendar year submit to the mayor and the council a written report on all activities and transactions of the department during the year 5 to attend council meetings the chief or other officer designated by himher shall attend all meetings of the council and under the direction of the presiding officer of the council shall preserve order and decorum 6 deposit of fees all license fees and other fees collected by the department shall be deposited with the clerktreasurer at least monthly on the first working day of the month 403  assistant chief duties  the assistant chief shall assume the duties of the chief in the absence of the chief 404  police powers  all police officers shall have such power and shall perform such duties as are prescribed by statutes of the state and federal governments all ordinances of the city and orders rules and regulations lawfully prescribed by the mayor or the council the chief and each policeman shall possess the powers enjoy the privileges and be subject to the liabilities conferred and imposed by law upon constables and be taken as included in all writs and papers addressed to constables shall arrest with or without process and with reasonable diligence take before the proper court every person in the city engaged in any disturbance of the peace or violation of any law of the state or ordinance of the city they shall collect the same fees allowed to constables for similar services it shall be their duty to familiarize themselves with provisions of the ordinances and all rules and regulations relating to police officers and govern themselves accordingly 405  who may arrest  am #2084 the chief of police and members of the police department with or without process or complaint may arrest retain and confine in such place as may be provided by the council until a trial can be had before a proper court any and all persons violating the ordinances or regulations of the city and any persons who shall be detected in the act of offending against any of the provisions of the laws of the state 406  search and seizure  the police officers of the city may search and seize with respect to violation of city ordinances under the same restrictions and rules governing search and seizure with respect to offenses against state statutes 407  police to inspect taverns  the chief of police shall see that each place in the city licensed to deal in fermented malt beverages or intoxicating liquor is periodically visited and inspected by a police officer and that a record of all violations complaints or unfavorable conditions is made at the police station 408  fires and assemblages  the chief of police or any other officer directed by himher shall attend all fires and tumultuous assemblages to direct traffic to save and protect property and to disperse mobs and arrest such persons as heshe may find disturbing the peace or aiding or abetting others in so doing 409  residency requirements  am #0404 upon completion of an officers probationary period every police officer shall reside and continue to reside either within the city limits or within such distance of city hall as shall be required by their employment agreement or labor agreement as may be applicable 410  badge to be displayed  am #189 all appointed officials having been delegated police power by law shall carry sufficient identification on their person at all times to be so identified and shall be subject to emergency mobilization by the chief of police should the need arise further all policemen when on duty shall wear the badge of their office on the outside of the outer garment conspicuously displaying the same so the entire surface thereof may be seen except when caution may dictate that the same shall not be exposed 411  arrests persons called to assist  all persons in the city when called upon by any police officer shall promptly aid and assist such officer in the execution of hisher duties failure or neglect to give such assistance shall be and constitute a violation of this section 412  interfering with or resisting police officer  any person in the city who shall willfully resist or in any way interfere with any police officer or member of the police department in the discharge of hisher duty or shall hinder or prevent himher from discharging hisher duty as such officer or member or shall offer or endeavor so to do and whoever shall in any manner assist any person in custody shall be subject to the penalty provided in sec 420 of this chapter 413  police not to give bail  the chief of police or other police officer shall in no case give bail for any person under arrest 414  regulation of emergency alarm systems  cr #398 1 definitions a false alarm any of the following 1 any signal message or other communication transmitted by an alarm system person or other device which causes police or fire department response in which it is determined by the city not to be of an existing emergency or unlawful situation 2 activation of an alarm system of the owner or lessee of an alarm or of its employees or agents 3 activation of an alarm system failure or malfunction 4 activation of an alarm system because of installation andor use of equipment by the alarm business this definition does not include false alarms caused by tornadoes severe thunder storms heavy snows or other similar occurrences b alarm business any business in which the owners or employees engage in the activity of altering installing leasing maintaining repairing replacing selling or servicing alarm systems 2 prohibited devices no person shall use or cause to be used any telephone or electronic device or attachment that automatically selects a public primary telephone trunk line of the police or fire department and then reproduces any prerecorded message to report any unlawful act fire or other emergency 3 prohibition against false alarms no person shall by means of an alarm system give a false alarm to any public officer or employee 4 permit required for alarm systems any business or private residence that installs an alarm system and requests that emergency services respond when activated are required to have a valid alarm system permit the permit is obtained application process the application for a permit may be obtained at the police department for a one time fee of $15 except that if a permit is revoked under the terms of this section the reapplication fee is $100 permits are not transferable 5 false alarms am #0807 a liability  no person shall cause the activation of a false alarm which causes police or fire department response the owner or employer is subject to vicarious liability under this section for the conduct of hisher employee who while acting within the scope of hisher employment causes the activation of a false alarm such owner or employer shall be liable under this section although the owner or employer did not directly activate the false alarm anyone including an alarm business whose conduct is a substantial factor in causing the activation of a false alarm is subject to liability under this section b exceptions  a violation shall not occur if special circumstances are presented to show that alarm system malfunctioned for reasons other than human error the police department shall develop administrative rules to ensure that proper notice is given to alarm system permit holders if a violation occurs a written warning will be given to the alarm system owner within 10 days of the first false alarm 6 penalties am #0807 a any person who shall violate the provisions of subsection 5 shall be subject to a forfeiture as follows 1 fire department responsefalse alarm a first occurrence no violation b second occurrence within one calendar year forfeiture of $10 plus court costs and fees c third fourth and fifth occurrence within one calendar year forfeiture of $25 plus court costs and fees d sixth or more occurrences within one calendar year forfeiture of $50 plus court costs and fees e upon 8 or more occurrences the fire department chief may order the permit revoked if a permit is revoked and another alarm response is required forfeiture of $200 plus court costs and fees 2 police department responseburglaryrobbery alarm a first second and third occurrence no violation b fourth occurrence within one calendar year forfeiture of $10 plus court costs and fees c fifth occurrence within one calendar year forfeiture of $25 plus court costs and fees d sixth or more occurrences forfeiture of $50 plus court costs and fees e upon 8 or more occurrences the chief of police may order the permit revoked if a permit is revoked and another response is required forfeiture of $200 plus court costs and fees b any person who violates subsections 2 and 3 above shall be subject to a forfeiture of not less than $50 nor more than $200 plus court costs and fees 420  penalty  any person who shall violate any provision of this chapter or any order rule or regulation made hereunder shall be subject to a penalty as provided in sec 2504 of this  fire department 501 fire department 502 fire chief powers and duties 503 assistant chiefs duties 504 fire inspector 505 false alarms 506 use of adjacent property 507 destruction of property to check progress of fire 508 apparatus to and from fires 509 traffic laws apply to volunteers 510 safety regulations 511 duty of bystanders 512 damage to equipment and interference 513 driving over fire hose 514 combustible materials 515 careless smoking prohibited 516 gasoline benzine naphtha etc 517 gunpowder 518 dynamite 525 penalty 501  fire department  1 composition the fire department of the city shall consist of the fire chief 4 assistant chiefs first second third and fourth assistant chiefs fire inspector secretarytreasurer and not less than 15 active firemen to make a minimum complement of 22 active firemen 2 appointment terms disciplinary actions the police and fire commission shall appoint the fire chief who shall hold office during good behavior subject to suspension or removal by the commission for cause the chief shall appoint subordinate members of the department subject to approval by the police and fire commission such appointments promotions suspensions and removals shall be made as provided in 6213 wis stats which section is hereby adopted by reference 3 regulations members of the department shall be governed by the rules and regulations adopted by the police and fire commission and resolutions and ordinances of the council and the wisconsin statutes 502  fire chief powers and duties  the fire chief shall direct the operation of the department at fires subject to the rules and regulations which may be adopted by the council and the police and fire commission issue and enforce such orders as in hisher judgment may be best calculated for the protection of property and the extinguishing of fires  enforce all ordinances and rules and regulations of the council governing the fire department  report annually to the council all fires occurring in the city the origin thereof if possible together with the amounts and value of property destroyed and the amount of insurance if any  make a full statement of the condition of the department at the end of each year and make further reports when ordered to do so by a resolution of the council or required to do so by the rules and regulations of the police and fire commission heshe shall report promptly to the commission any member of the department who may have disobeyed hisher orders or violated any of the rules governing the department and shall have control and supervision of the fire alarm 503  assistant chiefs duties  in the absence of the chief the highest ranking assistant chief shall take command and perform hisher duties 504  fire inspector  1 appointment the fire inspector shall be appointed by the fire chief and approved by the police and fire commission 2 powers and duties the fire inspector shall personally or her duly authorized deputy make such inspections as may be necessary to ascertain the compliance of the owners or occupants of private premises with the provisions of this chapter and heshe and hisher assistants may enter any building or upon any premises at any reasonable hour for the purpose of such inspection should heshe find a fire hazard heshe may serve a notice in writing on the owner of the property giving the owner 48 hours in which to remove the hazard if the fire hazard is not removed within that time it is deemed a nuisance and the fire inspector may have the same removed by the city and the cost of removal shall be recovered by the city as a special charge pursuant to  wis stats a frequency of inspections cr #07162016 the inspections shall be conducted at least once per calendar year the interval between those inspections shall not exceed 15 months 3 investigation and record of fires the fire inspector shall investigate the cause of all fires occurring within the city as soon as possible after their occurrence and heshe shall keep a record thereof and of the evidence in each case on file in hisher office as a public record 505  false alarms  whoever without reasonable cause by outcry or otherwise makes any false alarm of fire shall be penalized under sec 525 of this chapter 506  use of adjacent property  any fireman while acting under the order or direction of the chief or other officer in command may enter upon the premises adjacent to or in the vicinity of any building or other property then on fire for the purpose of extinguishing such fire and no person shall hinder or resist or obstruct any fireman in the discharge of such duty 507  destruction of property to check progress of fire  during the progress of any fire the fire chief or in hisher absence the assistant chief or squad leader in charge may order the removal or destruction of any property necessary to prevent the further spread of fire 508  apparatus to and from fires  except when actually responding to a fire alarm or other emergency call or when on duty at a fire the apparatus of the fire department shall have no special right of way or privileges of any kind but shall be subject to the same traffic regulations as other vehicles 509  traffic laws apply to volunteers  all volunteer firemen when responding to a fire call with a private vehicle shall comply with all traffic regulations 510  safety regulations  the chief or hisher designated agent may prescribe certain limits in the vicinity of any fire within which any persons excepting firemen and policemen and those admitted by order of any officer of the fire department shall not be permitted heshe may cause the removal of any property whenever it shall become necessary for the preservation of such property from fire or to prevent the spreading of fire or to protect adjoining property heshe may likewise cause the shutoff of electrical and natural gas services where the same create a dangerous hazard or interfere with the work of the fire department during the progress of the fire 511  duty of bystanders  every person who may be present at a fire shall be subject to orders of the chief or other officer in command and every such person shall render assistance as may be ordered by the officer in charge any person who shall refuse to obey such order after the official status of the officer in charge shall be made known to himher shall be subject to a penalty as provided in sec 525 of this chapter 512  damage to equipment and interference  no person shall willfully hinder a fireman in the discharge of hisher duties nor shall any person willfully injure in any manner any hose fire engine or other fire apparatus belonging to the city 513  driving over fire hose  no road vehicle shall be driven over any fire hose unless otherwise directed by an officer of the city 514  combustible materials  no person shall permit on premises heshe controls any empty boxes waste paper excelsior rags or other combustible materials in such quantities or manner as to create a fire hazard 515  careless smoking prohibited  1 no person shall by careless or willful smoking or use of lighters or matches in smoking whether intentional or unintentional set fire to personal property or any building 2 a plainly printed notice of this section shall be posted in a conspicuous place in every sleeping room of every place renting rooms for the accommodation of the public such printed notices shall also be posted in any place of public assembly where smoking is permitted 3 the fire chief shall post or cause to be posted no smoking signs on any premises or in any building or any section of such premises or building where by the presence of highly combustible materials in hisher opinion the act of smoking presents a fire hazard such signs shall be not less than 10 inches by 12 inches in size and shall be posted conspicuously at intervals of not less than 30 feet such signs shall bear the words no smoking across the top in large letters state the authority by which they are posted in smaller letters and bear the signature of the fire chief or hisher duly authorized representative 4 candles or torches that are not in a fixed holder shall not be allowed to be burned lighted candles held in the hands shall not be allowed in any church or public building unless written permission is first obtained from the fire chief or assistant fire chief 516  gasoline benzine naphtha etc  all gasoline stations bulk gasoline storage facilities and any facility for storing benzine naphtha or any other volitile liquid shall be constructed and maintained in conformity with the regulations prescribed by the state statutes and the rules and regulations of the state department of industry labor and human relations 517  gunpowder  no person shall keep or store more than 5 pounds of gunpowder at any place within the city without the written permission of the fire chief any dealer permitted to keep at hisher place of business in excess of 5 pounds of gunpowder shall not keep more than 50 pounds at any one time and such gunpowder shall be kept in a safely constructed box painted yellow with the word powder printed or painted thereon in black letters not less than 5 inches in height and equipped with handles so that the same may be readily moved in case of fire and such box shall be kept in such part of the dealers place of business as may be directed by the fire chief 518  dynamite  no person shall keep or store within the city any nitroglycerine dynamite giant powder or other explosives more violent than gunpowder without the written permission of the fire chief or otherwise than in accordance with the conditions prescribed in such permission as granted and in no case shall more than 25 pounds of any such explosive be stored or kept within 20 roads of any dwelling or other occupied building the fire chief may direct the place and the manner of keeping the same and the precautions to be observed in connection therewith 525  penalty  any person who shall violate any provision of this chapter or any order rule or regulation made hereunder and any fireman who shall neglect or refuse to perform any duty required hereunder shall be subject to a penalty as provided in sec 2504 of this  emergency management rep & recr #0213 601 name 602 objective 603 policy and purpose 604 membership 605 committees 606 miscellaneous provisions 607 emergency response plan 608 rules 609 amendments 601  name the name of this organization shall be the city of waupaca local emergency planning committee of hereinafter referred to as the lepc 602  objective the role of the city of waupaca lepc is to form a partnership with local government agencies and industries as a resource for enhancing emergency response and preparedness local governments are responsible for the integration of hazmat and all hazards planning and response within the jurisdiction this includes ensuring the local hazard analysis adequately addresses hazmat incidents  incorporating planning for hazmat incidents into the local emergency management plan and annexes  assessing capabilities and developing hazmat response capability using local resources mutual aid and contractors  training responders  and exercising the plan 603  policy and purpose to ensure that the city of waupaca is capable of responding in the event of an emergency with the underlying goal of minimizing the effects from a disaster and ensure a timely recovery to accomplish this response training updating emergency response resource listings public awareness campaigns and improving communications between public agencies and the general public the purpose of the lepc shall be to carry out those responsibilities required pursuant to c of public law 99499 the emergency planning and community righttoknow act epcra of 198 also known as sara title iii and related regulations the plan shall be reviewed and updated as necessary on an annual basis in accordance with of sara title iii the lepc shall in addition 1 receive and process request for information from the public under the righttoknow provisions  2 with the information and reports from facilities operating within the jurisdiction of the lepc and an analysis of the districts transportation risks the lepc will perform a hazard analysis  3 establish and maintain a database of hazardous chemical locations and quantities in the district  4 establish and maintain a computerized system of data management  5 maintain detailed information on all facilities which manufactures or stores extremely hazardous substances ehs and include the information within the emergency response and preparedness plan  6 develop training and testing of a emergency response plan the lepc will make assessments of resources necessary to implement the emergency response and preparedness plan and make recommendations to appropriate people agencies and organizations regarding additional resources needed to implement the plan the lepc shall be instrumental in fulfilling the purpose of the community righttoknow laws to increase the protection of the community from exposure to chemicals produced used stored andor transported within the city transportation hazards analysis will include those risks to the district from commercial transportation by rail highway aircraft and waters of commerce 604  membership membership will at all times include at a minimum representatives of the groups listed in of sara title iii at a minimum the committee shall have equal representation from  local elected officials  city of waupaca office of emergency management  city of waupaca dept of public works  city assessor  city administrative departments  waupaca police dept  waupaca area fire district  waupaca area ambulance  waupaca county 911  riverside medical center  disaster relief agencies red cross or salvation army  broadcast and print media personnel  community groups  owners or operators of local facilities the members will be appointed by the mayor of the city of waupaca and approved by the city of waupaca common council the responsibilities of the committee shall include the review and update of the city of waupaca emergency operations plan as necessary exercising or training on the plan implementing public awareness programs ensuring compliance with ch 323 wis stats governing emergency government assisting with federal emergency management agency fema and state of wisconsin disaster reporting and any other activity that will complement or enhance emergency planning and response in the city the membership of the lepc shall consist of officers and a staff the officers may consist of a chairperson a vicechairperson emergency management coordinator an information coordinator and a secretary 1 terms of membership members shall be residents of or have a business affiliation in city of waupaca 2 terms of office membership of the lepc may select the terms of office to be either one or 2 years existing officers may be reelected to their existing offices if they so indicate a willingness to continue 3 the chairperson the appointed alderman shall serve as the chairman of the lepc the chairperson shall preside at all meetings of the lepc unless heshe cannot be present at an announced meeting the chairperson shall serve as an exofficio member of all committees and shall perform such duties and acts as necessary to accomplish the goals of the lepc the chairperson shall be empowered to create such other ad hoc committees as necessary to accomplish the goals of the lepc 4 the vicechairperson upon resignation or death or the advice of the chairperson the vicechairperson shall perform the duties of the chairperson the vice chairperson shall perform such other duties as may be assigned by the chairperson 5 the secretary the secretary in cooperation with the information coordinator shall be the custodian of all books papers documents and other property of the lepc 6 emergency management coordinator the emergency management coordinator position shall be appointed by the mayor with confirmation by common council the position shall serve a term of oneyear the emergency management coordinator shall serve on the city of waupaca lepc and fulfill the roles activities and responsibilities of the position identified in ch 323 wis stats 7 the information coordinator the lepc will appoint an information coordinator this person will process request from the public for information under including tier two information under the coordinator will assist the secretary in records management the information coordinator will be a nonvoting member of all committees of the lepc 8 inactive members appointed members shall be considered inactive when heshe have missed more than 2 unexcused committee meetings without notification to the committee chair of significant reason why they were unable to attend the meetings an annual report listing members declared inactive will be provided to the executive advisory panel and the lepc 9 removal of members the city of waupaca lepc may ask that the mayor remove a member from its roll 10 vacancies any vacancy occurring in the lepc by reason of resignation death or disqualification of a member will be filled by the nomination of the lepc chairperson and appointed by the mayor 11 alternates every approved member of the lepc committee may select an alternate to attend meetings in hisher absence the alternate may participate in discussions and will have voting rights if both the regular member and hisher alternate are in attendance at a regular scheduled lepc meeting the regular members privileges and responsibilities will supersede those of hisher respective alternate 605  committees 1 executive advisory panel the executive advisory panel will consist of the lepc chairperson vicechairperson secretary and emergency management coordinator the duties of the executive advisory panel will assist in coordinating the activities of the subcommittee and ad hoc committees 2 subcommittees the following subcommittees may be established a righttoknow subcommittee  this committee will be responsible for the formulation of all policies and procedures concerning the publics righttoknow program  the formulation of all chemical release reporting procedures the establishment of trade secret protection procedures and the formulation of all record keeping and information dissemination procedures for the lepc b emergency management subcommittee  this committee will be responsible for reporting the status of nims training state and national emergency management initiatives emergency management logistics and the coordination between the city of waupaca and waupaca county emergency management c training and exercise subcommittee  this committee will be responsible for the coordination of multi agency collective training and exercises d law enforcementcommunications subcommittee  this committee will be responsible for reporting the coordinating efforts of law order and security agencies and coordination and implementation of interoperable communications between first responding agencies within city of waupaca e fire services subcommittee  this committee will be responsible for reporting the status of resources assets training personnel and mutual aid agreements as it pertains to fire support functions search and rescue and hazmat response within the city of waupaca f emergency medical services and hospitals subcommittee  this committee will report on the coordination and planning efforts between ems first responders and hospital g public works subcommittee  this committee will be responsible for reporting the status of and coordinating the emergency management efforts between the city of waupaca department of public works and corresponding agencies within all municipalities h transportation and evacuation subcommittee  this committee will be responsible for reporting the status of transportation resources and evacuation planning i mass care and shelter task force subcommittee  this committee will be responsible for reporting the coordination efforts with the american red cross and all faith based organizations as it pertains to mass care and sheltering operations j social services committee  this committee will be responsible for reporting the status of social and mental health services under emergency conditions k public alerting information and education subcommittee  this committee will be responsible for reviewing the public alerting and notification systems  public relations with affected communities and the public at large and development of public awareness education and information programs l volunteers and donations subcommittee  this committee will be responsible for coordinating with regional volunteers and faith based organizations m animal control subcommittee  this committee will be responsible for the sheltering evacuation and rescue of domesticated animals 3 ad hoc committees the chairperson may create the ad hoc committee as necessary to perform the functions of the lepc chairpersons of ad hoc committees shall be appointed by the chairperson of the lepc 4 chairpersons of the subcommittees the chairperson of the subcommittee shall be nominated and elected by their respective committees the election shall be by ballot except that when there is only one nomination for each office election may be by voice vote 5 memberships in subcommittees all members must volunteer to serve on at least one subcommittee and shall not serve on more than 3 subcommittees final membership of the subcommittee shall be determined by the chairperson after consultation with the executive advisory panel to ensure that all committees have sufficient manpower to carry out their assigned tasks 6 meetings meetings of the subcommittee and ad hoc committees may be called by the chairperson of the lepc or the chair of the committee as deemed necessary a regular meetings  the lepc committee and subcommittees shall meet at a minimum bimonthly b special meetings  the lepc chairperson may call such special meetings as may be deemed necessary to carry out duties of the lepc upon the written request of at least 50 percent of the members the lepc chairperson shall call a meeting within 10 days 7 quorum a quorum shall consist of a majority of the lepc members excluding those members declared to be inactive a quorum shall be required to transact business 8 annual report annually in may of each year the committee shall prepare a written report to the common council detailing the activities undertaken for the previous year 9 agenda any member may request that the lepc chairperson place an item on the meeting agenda if the chairperson should decline to do so a member may have such item placed on the agenda by submitting it in writing to the chairperson with support signatures of 50 percent of the members 10 rules of order the deliberations of all meetings of the lepc and its subcommittees shall be governed by roberts rules of order 11 notice of meetings notice of time date place of meeting and agenda items to be considered at each meeting shall be given in writing to all members at least 6 days prior to each meeting by the staff or the lepc chairperson a notice of the regular meeting schedule of the lepc shall be published and posted at city hall and available to the media with regular circulation in city of waupaca in accordance with sara title iii epcra this notice shall specify the meeting designated specifically for receipt of public comments on the emergency plan 606  miscellaneous provisions 1 fiscal year the fiscal year shall be considered to run from january 1 to december 31 2 indebtedness all indebtedness incurred by the lepc shall be approved by the lepc chairperson before payment 3 approval of bylaws these bylaws shall become effective upon approval of majority vote by those in attendance at an organized meeting 4 disqualification any member who is unable to attend a meeting of the lepc may notify the chairman or secretary any member with 5 or more absences is subject to disqualification at the request of the lepc chairperson this disqualification request will be forwarded to the mayor for final approval 607  emergency response plan the lepc committee is responsible for the development and update of the city of waupaca emergency response plan the plan is designed to complement and reference back to the waupaca county emergency response plan there shall be training or exercising of the plan on a periodic basis to allow emergency response agencies within the city an opportunity to train 608  rules epcra requires that the lepc shall establish rules by which the committee shall function such rules shall include provisions for public notification of committee activities public meetings to discuss the emergency plan public comments response to such comments by the committee and distribution of the emergency plan 1 method of initiating proposed rulemaking any member of the lepc may recommend the initiation of proposed rulemaking any proposed rules shall be initially considered by the executive advisory panel unless otherwise decided by the lepc if the executive advisory panel by majority vote approves the proposed rule it shall thereafter proceed to publication as provided in the preceding section 2 method of adopting final rules following the expiration of the 10day comment period the executive advisory panel shall review all public comments and prepare a statement which responds to comments raised and discusses the basis for any appropriate changes to the proposal the executive advisory panel shall present such statement to the lepc the lepc shall then vote on the adoption of the proposed rule if the vote is favorable the rule shall take effect immediately upon the time and date the notice of adoption is first published 3 emergency rules in emergency circumstances the lepc may adopt rules without prior public notice and comment provided that no such rule will remain in effect for more than 90 days 4 in accordance with of the sara title iii act all information obtained from an owner or operator pursuant with epcra and any requested tier two forms or material safety data sheet msds otherwise in possession of the lepc shall be made available to any person submitting a written request under this section if the owner should request the location of a specified chemical not be identified the lepc shall withhold that information 5 all photocopied information requests by a member of the public shall be provided at the sole expense of the requestors the cost of such reproduction shall be set by the information coordinator with the approval of the executive advisory panel at a level that will enable the lepc to recover all reasonable expenses associated with the processing of the request 6 request for msdss and other nonconfidential information any person may obtain an msds with respect to a specific facility by submitting a written request to the lepc information coordinator the facility shall provide the msds copy with within 45 days of the written request any person may request any other nonconfidential information concerning a facility which may be held by the lepc by submitting a written request to the lepc information coordinator 7 requests for tier two information any person may request tier two information with respect to a specific facility by submitting a written request to the lepc in accordance with the following requirements a if the committee does not have in its possession the tier two information as requested it shall request a submission of the particular tier two form from the owner or operator of the facility subject to the request provided that the request is from a state or local official acting in his or her official capacity or the request is limited to hazardous chemicals stored at the facility in an amount in excess of the threshold planning quantity b if the request does not meet the requirements of the lepc may request submission of the tier two form from the owner or operator of the facility subject to the request if the request includes a general statement of need 8 the city of waupaca lepc shall take an all hazard approach when conducting risk assessments and emergency planning within the city 609  amendments these bylaws may be amended as necessary these bylaws may be amended by the waupaca common council any member of the lepc shall have the right to comment on or suggest revisions to the bylaws chapter 7  traffic code 701 state traffic laws adopted 702 official traffic map and control devices prohibited signs signals and markers 703 speed limits 704 through highways  one way streets 705 parking regulations 706 abandoned vehicles 707 accident reports 708 disorderly conduct with a motor vehicle 709 school bus warning lights 710 parking during snowstorm emergency 711 traffic and parking regulations on school district grounds 712 operation and parking of motor vehicles in public parking obstruction of railroad crossings 714 snowmobiles 715 waupaca municipal airport  regulation of vehicular and pedestrian traffic  public works short term work sites  compression brakes prohibited 716 penalties 717 enforcement 718 references to wisconsin statutes 719 weight restriction 701  state traffic laws adopted  rep & recr #1302  am #1103 except as otherwise specifically provided in this chapter the statutory provisions in   and chs 340 to 348 wis stats describing and defining regulations with respect to vehicles and traffic exclusive of any provisions therein relating to penalties to be imposed and exclusive of any regulations for which the statutory penalty is a fine or term of imprisonment are hereby adopted and by reference made a part of this chapter as if fully set forth herein any act required to be performed or prohibited by any statute incorporated herein by reference is required or prohibited by this chapter any future amendments revisions or modifications of the statutes incorporated herein are intended to be made part of this chapter in order to secure uniform statewide regulation of traffic on the highways streets and alleys of the state of wisconsin 702  official traffic map and control devices  prohibited signs signals and markers  rep & recr #1802 1 duty of the director of public works to erect and install uniform traffic control devices whenever traffic regulations created by this chapter including a state traffic regulation adopted by reference in sec 701 of this chapter require the erection of traffic control devices for enforcement the director of public works shall procure erect and maintain uniform traffic control devices conforming to the uniform traffic control device manual promulgated by the wisconsin department of transportation giving notice of such traffic regulations to the users of the streets and highways on which such regulations apply whenever state law grants discretion to local authorities in erecting or placing of a uniform traffic control devices devices shall be erected in such locations and in such a manner as in the judgment of the director of public works will carry out the purposes of this chapter and give adequate warning to users of the streets and highways of the city 2 official traffic map a official traffic map established  the there is hereby established for the city of waupaca an official traffic map dated  by msa professional services of baraboo wisconsin upon which is indicated as of said date all existing traffic signage including no parking areas restricted parking areas stop signs arterial intersections yield signs special speed limits one way highways school crossings signs and all other restrictions or limitations contained in this chapter and which the laws of the state require the erection or use of official traffic control devices to enforce such restrictions or limitations all such signage restrictions and limitations set forth on said official traffic map are hereby adopted ratified and affirmed b additions deletions or changes to map  the common council may from time to time make additions deletions or changes to the official traffic map every addition deletion or change to the official traffic map shall indicate the number of the authorizing ordinance or resolution and the date the traffic control device was erected altered or eliminated c official traffic map to be maintained  a copy of the official traffic map shall be maintained and displayed in the office of the city assessorbuilding inspector the police department and public works department the city assessorbuilding inspectors office shall be charged with the upkeep and maintenance of the official traffic map and in so doing shall make appropriate authorized changes by hand within 3 working days after the official traffic control device is erected or removed as the case may be periodically but no less than every 3 years the official traffic map shall be updated to include all additions deletions or changes that have been made to the map by hand over the previous time period d violations prohibited  when official traffic control devices giving notice of restrictions prohibitions and limitations shown on the official traffic map are erected and maintained in accordance with the provisions of this section a violation of the restriction prohibition or limitation shown on the official traffic map shall be a violation of the provisions of this chapter 3 prohibited signs and markers in highways no person other than a city official authorized by this chapter to erect and maintain official traffic control devices or hisher designee shall place within the limits of any street or highway maintained by the city any sign signal marker mark or monument unless permission is first obtained for the director of public works or the state highway commission any sign signal marker mark or monument placed or maintained in violation of this subsection shall be subject to removal as provided in sub 4 below 4 removal of unofficial signs markers signals and traffic control devices the director of public works or hisher designee may remove any sign signal marker or device which is placed maintained or displayed in violation of this chapter or state law any charge imposed against a premises for removal of a prohibited or illegal sign signal marker or device shall be reported by the director of public works to the common council for review and certification at its next regular meeting following the imposition of the charge any charge not paid on or before the next succeeding november 15 shall be placed upon the tax roll for collection as other special municipal taxes 703  speed limits  rep & recr #0610 the council hereby determines that the statutory speed limits on the following city streets excluding township county or state roadways or highways or portions thereof are unreasonable unsafe and imprudent and modifies such speed limits as follows 1 speed limits changes speed limits are increased or decreased as follows upon the following designated city streets excluding township county or state roadways or highways or portions thereof a 35 miles per hour  apple tree lane farm drive to runway drivecommercial drive commercial drive apple tree lane to east end runway drive apple tree lane to east end churchill street apple tree lane to evans street ware street mainline railroad rightofway east of miller street to tower road cth k royalton street matheson street to tower road cth k b speed limit on alleys  the speed on any alley located within the city shall not exceed 5 miles per hour 704  through highways  1 through highways designated in the interest of public safety and pursuant to authority granted by wisconsin law the council by resolution has previously declared certain highways or portions thereof to be 2 designation of location of stop signs and yield signs in the interest of public safety the council by resolution has designated the location of stop and yield signs within the city and has ordered the installation of such signs 3 operators to obey traffic control devices every operator of a vehicle approaching an intersection at which an official traffic control device is erected in accordance with this section shall obey the direction of such official traffic control device as required by the wisconsin statutes incorporated by reference in sec 701 of this chapter operators of vehicles approaching a stop sign shall stop before entering a highway as required by 34546 wis stats operators approaching intersections at which a yield sign has been installed shall yield the right of way to other vehicles as required by 346185 wis stats   one way streets  rep & recr #0314 the following streets are designated oneway streets and no person shall operate a vehicle thereon in any direction except as follows 1 granite street  northwesterly only from hillcrest drive to morton street 2 shearer street  southeasterly only from van street to school street 3 van street  northerly from school street to shearer street 705  parking regulations  1 parking prohibited during certain periods no person shall park or leave standing any vehicle or personal property for longer than 30 minutes between  am and  am upon any parking lot in which the city has an interest except the parking lot located at the southwest corner of the intersection of south washington street and west union street and the parking lot know as riverside parking lot located between north main street and the waupaca river 2 stopping standing or parking of vehicles the authority vested in the council under 34913 wis stats to prohibit limit the time of or otherwise restrict the stopping standing or parking of vehicles beyond the prohibitions limitations or restrictions imposed by ch 346 wis stats is delegated to the chief of police 3 no parking except for authorized vehicles except as herein permitted no person shall park stop or leave standing any vehicle in the following places unless authorized by an official traffic control sign a at any curb area marked as a taxi stop or stand b at any curb or municipal parking lot area designated as parking for city personnel 4 parking zone regulations rep & recr #382 a definitions  whenever in this subsection the following terms are used they shall have the meaning respectively ascribed to them in this section 1 street every way set apart for public travel except alley ways bridle paths and foot paths 2 roadway that portion of a street between curb lines and the adjacent property lines 3 vehicle any device by which any person or property may be transported upon a public highway except those operated upon rails and permanent tracks 4 parking zone a certain designated and markedoff section of the public street within the marked boundaries where the vehicle may be temporarily parked and allowed to remain for such period of time as the parking zone area signs hereinafter referred to may indicate b parking zones  parking zones as defined in par a4 above are hereby created on the following streets of the city 1 main street between granite street and the south line of the us post office premises extended east on both sides 2 granite street between main street and washington street on both sides 3 sessions street between main street and washington street on both sides 4 fulton street between jefferson street and washington street on both sides 5 union street between division street and washington street on both sides 6 badger street between main street and washington street on both sides 7 jefferson street between fulton street and badger street on both sides 8 washington street between west fulton street and badger street on both sides 9 from time to time hereafter as traffic conditions require on such streets and avenues or such other locations as selected by resolution of the council for the location of such zones c limitations on parking  in said parking zones no person shall cause a vehicle to be parked for a period of time in excess of the following times on the following named streets or portions thereof 1 15 minute parking am #1004  #0208 a on south main street from badger street to the south line of the us post office premises extended east b on the west side of south washington street from union street to the north line of the police department premises extended east 2 8 hour parking am #1004  am #1218 on the east and west side of jefferson street from east union street to east fulton street including parking in the adjacent city halllibrary parking lot within this block unless signed otherwise 3 2 hour parking am #1004 all other parking zones a to restrict parking along the north side of badger street between franklin street and washington street all to 2hour parking limit cr #1113 4 parking prohibited in certain specified places  cr #187 no person shall stop or leave standing in any of the following places except temporarily for the purpose of and while actually engaged in loading or unloading or receiving or discharging passengers and while the vehicle is attended by a licensed operator so that it may promptly be moved in case of an emergency or to avoid obstruction of traffic a in a loading zone but in no case shall a vehicle be stopped or left standing in a passenger loading zone in excess of 3 minutes nor in a freight loading zone in excess of 30 minutes the parking restrictions of this subparagraph shall be applicable only during the hours specified on official signs b in an alley in a business district c in any street or alley which is less than 18 feet wide from curb to curb d within 10 feet of a fire hydrant unless a greater distance is indicated by an official traffic sign e within 4 feet of the entrance to an alley or private road or driveway or bicycle way f closer than 20 feet to the near limits of a marked crosswalk g upon any portion of a highway where and at the time when parking is prohibited limited or restricted by official traffic signs h upon any portion of a street right of way between the curb line or the edge of the roadway and the property line said space being commonly known as the terrace except for bicycle parking am #2404 i on a street adjacent to the entrance of a school church theater hotel hospital or any other place of public assemblage during the hours designated by an official sign j not closer than 30 feet upon the approach to any flashing beacon stop sign or traffic control signal located at the side of a street k upon any bridge or other elevated structure upon a street or within a street tunnel except parking shall be allowed on the bridge located on water street am #0503 l on both sides of evans street at all times cr #1396 m on the south side of riverside drive between churchill street and
